sentences.sentence: The Farmer and the Dogs
During a cold winter, a farmer was trapped( 被困 ) in his house by the snow.
As he could not get any food from outside, he began eating his own sheep.
As the cold weather continued, he began to eat his goats( 山羊 ).
And finally—for there was no change in the cold weather—he ate the oxen( 阉牛 ) who worked on the farm.
Then the dogs said to one another,
“We should leave at once.
If the master( 主人 ) eats even the oxen( 阉牛 ), who do all the work around here, do you think he won’t eat us?”
MORAL: Learn from the misfortunes( 不幸 ) of others, not just from your own.
The Farmer and the Donkey( 驴 )
An old farmer was sitting in a field watching his donkey( 驴 ),
when all of a sudden he caught sight of( 看见 ) some soldiers( 士兵 ) moving towards them.
He jumped up in a moment, and asked the donkey( 驴 ) to escape( 逃跑 ) with him as fast as he could,
“Or else,” said he, “we shall both be captured( 被俘虏 ) by the enemy.”
But the donkey( 驴 ) just looked round lazily and said,
“And if so, do you think they’ll make me carry heavier loads( 负载物 ) than I have to now?”
“No,” said his master( 主人 ).
“Oh, well, then,” said the donkey( 驴 ),“I don’t mind if they do take me, for I shan’t be any worse off.”
MORAL: The poor may not fear a change of masters( 主人 ) in the way that the rich do.
The Farmer and the Fox( 狐狸 )
A farmer was greatly annoyed( 被激怒 ) by a fox( 狐狸 ), which came into his yard at night and carried off his chickens.
So he set a trap( 陷阱 ) for him and caught him;
and in order to get revenge( 报复 ) upon the fox( 狐狸 ),
the farmer tied a bunch of( 一扎 ) cloth( 布料 ) to his tail, set fire to( 点燃 ) it and let him go.
As ill-luck would have it, however, the fox( 狐狸 ) made straight for( 一直向...走去 ) the fields where the corn was standing ripe( 成熟的 ) and ready for cutting.
The corn quickly caught fire( 着火 ) and was all burnt up( 烧光 ), and the farmer lost all his harvest( 收成 ).
MORAL: Revenge( 报复 ) is a two-edged sword( 剑 ).
The Farmer and the Goats( 山羊 )
It was a stormy day, and the snow was falling fast.
A farmer led his goats( 山羊 ), all white with snow, into a cave( 洞穴 ) for shelter( 避难 ).
There, he found a group of wild goats( 山羊 ), more in number and larger than his own.
At the end of the day he drove both the wild goats( 山羊 ) and his own goats( 山羊 ) home and put them all into the pen( （羊）圈 ) together.
Next day the weather was so bad that he could not take them out as usual:
so he kept them at home in the farmyard( 农场 ), and fed( 喂养 ) them there.
He only gave his own goats( 山羊 ) enough food to keep them from( 避免 ) starving( 挨饿 ),
but he gave the wild goats( 山羊 ) as much as they could eat and more;
for he was very anxious( 渴望的 ) for them to stay,
and he thought that if he fed( 喂养 ) them well they wouldn’t want to leave him.
When the weather got better, he took them all out to fields again;
but when they got near the hills, the wild goats( 山羊 ) ran off.
The farmer was very angry at this, and said,
“How can you run away like that after the way I’ve treated you!”
Hearing this, one of them turned round and said,
“Oh, yes, you treated us all right—too well, in fact;
it was just that fact that got us thinking.
If you treat newcomers like ourselves so much better than your own goats( 山羊 ),
it’s more than likely that, if another lot of strange goats( 山羊 ) joined yours,
you would probably give them our food and we would go hungry.”
MORAL: They who ignore( 忽视 ) their old friends for new ones deserve( 应受 ) to lose both.

article_info.previous: 在昨天的故事中，自不量力的乌鸦想学老鹰抓走绵羊，最后爪子陷入羊毛中，被农夫抓住成为孩子们的玩物，这个故事告诉我们不自量力的人的下场都是很惨的。
article_info.share_words: Learn from the misfortunes of others, not just from your own.    Revenge is a two-edged sword.

question.cn: 在故事The Farmer and the Dogs中，农民为什么要吃自己的动物？
question.en: In the story the Farmer and the Dogs, why did the farmer eat his own animals?

options.en: He couldn't go out to find food.

options.cn: 他的动物太老了，干不动活。
options.en: His animals were too old to work.

analysis: 文中提到：“A farmer was trapped in his house by the snow, as he could not get any food from outside.” 农民被雪困在家里，没办法出去找吃的，因此选A。

question.cn: 在故事The Farmer and the Donkey中，当农夫驱赶驴逃跑的时候驴是怎么行动的？
question.en: In the story the Farmer and the Donkey, what did the donkey do when his master asked him to escape?

options.en: He ran as fast as possible.

options.cn: 驴懒散地四处张望，没有跑。
options.en: He looked around lazily and didn't run.

analysis: 文中提到：“but the donkey just looked round lazily.”并且由后面驴和农夫的对话中可以发现驴并不怕被抓，推测驴并没有快速逃跑，因此选B。

question.cn: 在故事The Farmer and the Fox中，农夫怎么报复狐狸的？
question.en: In the story the Farmer and the Fox, How did the farmer get revenge on the fox?

options.cn: 农夫把狐狸关到了笼子里面。
options.en: The farmer locked the fox in a cage.

options.cn: 农夫把一束布料绑在狐狸尾巴上并点燃。
options.en: The farmer fastened a bundle of cloth to the fox's tail and set fire on it.

analysis: 文中提到：“The farmer tied a bunch of cloth to his tail, set fire to it.”农夫把一束布料绑在狐狸尾巴上，并点燃布料，因此选C。

question.cn: 在故事The Farmer and the Goats中，农夫在洞穴中发现了什么？
question.en: In the story the Farmer and the Goats, what did the farmer find in the cave?

analysis: 文中提到：“He found a group of wild goats.”可知农夫在洞穴中发现了一群野山羊，因此选A。

question.cn: 在故事The Farmer and the Goats结尾，野山羊是否留在了农夫的家里？
question.en: At the end of the story the Farmer and the Goats, did the wild goats stay in the farmer's home?

analysis: 文中提到：“When they got near the hill, the wild goats ran off.”以及后面的对话可知，这些野山羊最终还是跑走了，并没有留在农夫家里，因此选B。
